titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. After dinner I walk’d down to my father’s—took George with me; left him there and proceeded to the Bridge; where was to be a meeting of the Directors— Just before I reached the Bridge, Mr: Apthorp overtook me, and took me up— We found Mr: Quincy there; but no other of the Directors attended.— Mr: Apthorp took me home, and we stopp’d and took in George at my father’s— Read to the Ladies “the Lottery,” from the popular tales.

2. Besides the usual Chapter of Aristotle’s Rhetoric, which I read this afternoon at my fathers, I read over part of the Phaedrus of Plato, in the latin translation annexed to the edition of Henry Stephens.— Left George at my father’s this Evening— My Mother who called here with my Sister this morning had taken him with her— Read in the Evening, “Rosanna,” in the popular Tales.

3. Wrote rather more than usual this morning, but in the afternoon, I could not get through a whole chapter of Aristotle— The Ladies are tired of the Popular Tales, thinking them too much alike, and I read to them the 7th: Book of the Metamorphoses; translated by Tate and Stonestreet. It is not one of the best Books in the Original; and is tedious in the translation. The Story of Medea and Jason is too long; and the death of Pelias, shocking; no reason appearing for Medea’s cruelty.— The tale of Cephalus and Procris, is interesting; and yet all its pathetic rests upon a miserable pun.— Mr: Quincy was at my father’s this Evening.

4. At my father’s this afternoon I barely finished the Chapter of Aristotle I had begun yesterday— My attention was diverted from it, by some papers of my father’s, which was no loss of Time— But this very propensity to fly from the most urgent object of study to any thing else, is to me the most pernicious of Enemies— It prevents me from acquiring a profound knowledge of any thing; or from turning the little knowledge I do get, to proper advantage— The Ladies being tired of Ovid, I began this Evening, to read to them Marshall’s life of Washington.

5. Settled accounts with Mr: Briesler for the year— While at my father’s this afternoon my brother, and his wife returned from Boston— My Mother and Sister pass’d the afternoon at my house— I had barely time to read one Chapter of Aristotle this afternoon, without analyzing any part of it. In the Evening, I read “Murad the Unlucky” and “the Manufacturers,” in the popular tales; concluding the second Volume.

6. Heard Mr: Whitney, who preached the whole day from one text. Prov: XXIV.l0.—“If thou faint in the day of Adversity, thy strength is small.” It was an occasional sermon of comfort to several of his parishioners, who have recently been bereft of children; by a distemper which prevails much at this Season— He drew from his text and the occasion the usual and obvious topics of consolation. I gave an hour to Aristotle, in the afternoon— Read Sterne’s Sermons XXIII. on the Parable of the rich Man and Lazarus; a charity Sermon, XXIV. on Pride and XXV. On Humility. The course of Argument in these two is the same— The dissuasive from the vice, and the exhortation to the Virtue naturally go together; and they are both very good Sermons. It has been objected against the Christian Religion that it carries its doctrine of Humility to excess; but Pride is so universal and so inexpugnible, as well as so mischievous a Passion, that it cannot be encountered by too strong an opponent— The marks of hasty composition appear in these discourses as in most of the former— Sterne’s greatest defect of Style is the length, and complication of his Sentences— He begins to express a thought, and before he has got half through, it suggests some collateral idea, which he instantly takes in; that leads to another, and so on ad infinitum— At least so it would be; but that the necessity of finishing somewhere, brings him to at last; and after a page of rambling, when he comes to conclude his period, he often is very awkward at connecting the end, with the point of departure.— Style, says Gibbon is an image of Character— And so it is with Sterne— It is all Genius and Eccentricity.— In the Evening I read Fléchier’s funeral Oration on the Queen of France, Louis XIV.’s wife.— Last Sunday I had read that of the first President Lamoignon.— The style is the same, as in the former discourses upon like Occasions— Except that in the last there is a quaintness of thought in some instances, which seems the result of an embarrassment to say much where there was little to say— Fléchier praises the King, more than the Queen— Praises him too for things not very praise-worthy— His Persecution of the Protestants, and his Necessary Wars. Yet Fléchier was a good Man—full of humanity. And incapable of courtly flattery.— He was blinded by his religion, into one part of this applause, and dazzled by the Splendour of Lewis’s victories into the other—

7. Tea at Mr: Black’s, with my father’s family. This afternoon, besides my usual analysis of a chapter in Aristotle, I read the preface of Mr: Locke’s paraphrase and commentary on the Epistles of Saint Paul— As I am now reading them in the Greek Testament, I perceive more sensibly than ever before that they are full of difficulties other than those of the language; and though I have often read, I am far from Understanding them— They were difficult even to his cotemporaries, as appears by 2. Peter III.16. and must be still more so at this day, to much more learned readers than I am. Mr: Locke in his preface mentions several causes which have contributed to increase their obscurity, two of which are certainly just— Their division into Chapters and verses; and the practice of reading them, by parcels; and not a whole Epistle at one time— I must take an opportunity as soon as possible to read Mr: Locke’s paraphrase and notes; and seek other helps for making myself well acquainted with these important parts of the Scriptures.— Pass’d the Evening at home in Conversation— Mr: Loud, in my brother’s Office.

8. Mr: Boylston called on me this morning, respecting the appointment to the Professorship of Rhetoric and Oratory, founded by his uncle Nicholas Boylston, at Harvard College.— In Conversation with him, I stated to him the difficulties which yet prevent my acceptance of the place— I went with him and dined at my father’s; though we found they had dined before we arrived— My brother was at Dedham— Captain Richard Beale also called upon me respecting a claim he has against the Government. My reading was accordingly interrupted; but in the Evening I read a Chapter of Marshall.

9. Analysis of a Chapter in Aristotle, this afternoon; and wrote more than usual in the morning. My Mother and Sister were not at home— But I met them on my return. I find I have overtasked myself with study, and that I cannot go through so much as I have undertaken.

10. I went into Boston this morning with Mrs: Adams and returned at Night. It rained great part of the day; and we had an unpleasant time in coming home— The days are now so short, that we had but little time to stay. I saw Mr: Pearson and Judge Davis, respecting the Professorship at Cambridge, and they requested me to write again, stating my objection to the last vote of the Corporation; which I promised to do. I also saw Mr: Boylston, and transacted some business for my father.— Dined with Mr: J. Gardner.— All my usual occupations were of course interrupted; excepting the Stanza’s of the Racines Greques, which I did not omit.

11. Mrs: Adams was unwell all the morning, but about noon was seized with a violent, fainting fit— She was very ill all the remainder of the day, and confined to her bed— My Sister Smith and her daughter, Caroline pass’d the afternoon here— My father also call’d towards Evening— I could of course read little or nothing this day; but I wrote a letter to the Corporation of Harvard College.

12. Mrs: Adams was much better— In the afternoon I was at the lower Office, and read a Chapter of Aristotle. Writing to the Corporation of the College, and other occasional employments interrupted again most of my usual occupations— Evening at home in conversation.

13. Heard Mr: Whitney the whole day— His morning Sermon was from Philippians III.18. and consisted of an enumeration of the enemies to the Cross of Christ— In the afternoon the text was named before I came; but was from 1. Peter V.8. on the duty of vigilance— I dined and spent the afternoon at my father’s— Came home with the Ladies— Miss Harrod, a Cousin, of my brother’s wife came from Boston with Mr: Shaw, who went and dined at Weymouth. He called in the Evening at my house— Mr: T. Greenleaf took my letter for the College Corporation— I read Sterne’s Sermons XXVI—on Christian Wisdom— XXVII. On Conscience (the Shandy Sermon.) and XXVIII. On the temporal advantages of Religion— Upon full reflection, I cannot approve that mixture of levity in the manner, which he has interwoven in all his devotional works. Religion’s ways are ways of pleasantness, but not of pleasantry— Where there is much of the king’s jester, one cannot avoid a suspicion, that the whole discourse is meant but as a joke— Seriousness and Sincerity seem so inseparable, that a preacher cannot abandon the first, without departing also from the last— Laughter is no enemy to truth; but is averse to instruction in duty— A Man may become wiser and better by a judicious perusal and meditation of Sterne’s Sermons; but he will learn more and more safely from Tillotson.— I also finished in the Greek Testament the second epistle to the Corinthians.

14. I drew a petition to Congress for Captain Richard C. Beale, which again partly interrupted my proper employment. Afternoon and Evening at my father’s.— There was company there— Mr: Quincy’s family— Captain Beale’s, and both the Messrs: Greenleaf’s— I came home with the Ladies— Read the Contrast— Being the first of the Popular Tales, in the third Volume.

15. My Mother here this forenoon. Mrs: D. Greenleaf, and Mrs: Blake in the afternoon. I found Mrs: Smith of Boston, at my father’s this afternoon. She returned to town early.— In the Evening I read the grateful Negro, and part of “Tomorrow” in the popular Tales.

16. Rain the whole day, which confined me almost entirely to the house. I was employed chiefly in packing up a trunk to be sent by water to Washington— Towards Evening I called upon Mr: Page, but he was not at home. Read two Chapters of Marshall, and finished the popular Tales, which are entertaining and Moral— The last of the third Volume, “To-morrow[”] is peculiarly good, and contains a lesson of excellent use if one could but make a proper use of it.

17. We finished packing our trunks to go by water, and sent them away this afternoon— Mr: Quincy called on me, to return some books— Mrs: Beale was here— Went to my father’s so late I could do nothing.— Read a Chapter of Marshall this Evening— But my studious occupations are broken up for the Winter—from this day.

18. The Ladies pass’d the afternoon at Mr: D. Greenleaf’s. I called for them there in the Evening; and after coming home read a Chapter of Marshall’s Introduction— My reading and writing is now so desultory that it is of little or no use— Though nearly through the Racines Grecques and Aristotle’s Rhetoric, I know not whether I shall finish them this Winter.

19. I went into Boston this morning with Eliza Johnson, who is to pay a visit of some days at Dr: Welsh’s— I returned alone in the Evening— Saw judge Davis, and Dr: Waterhouse— Dined with the Cadet Company at Concert Hall; on their anniversary— But to come home, I was obliged to leave them immediately after dinner.— On my return I stopp’d at my father’s, with whom the Saturday’s Club had dined.

20. Heard Mr: Tuckerman of Chelsea, in whose sermons I perceived nothing very remarkable, and who might be a very good speaker, if he had not contracted a very affected manner. Dined with all my family at my father’s. Mr: Stebbins, and Miss Harrod, a Sister of Mrs: T. B. Adams were there— We left George, and came home early in the Evening; stopp’d at Mr: Cranch’s— Mr: Barrett spent part of the Evening with us. Read Sterne’s Sermons XXIX. XXX. and XXXI.

21. The circuit Court of the United States this day commenced a Session in Boston, which on various accounts I was desirous to attend. Mrs: Adams wishing at the same time to pay a visit of a few days to the town; we went in this morning with a Chaise, which we sent out at Night. My Sister with her Son and daughter went also to Boston— She purposes to spend some days at Cambridge.— The Court was opened, and organized for business. Judge Cushing gave a short charge to the Grand-Jury; and adjourned to the morning— In the Evening I went with Mrs: A. and Eliza to the Play, where Othello was performed— The character of the hero, by Cooper; an actor much in favour with the public; but who is a mere imitator of Kemble— The part of Iago, by Usher was better fill’d—though he is confessedly an indifferent performer.— The farce was Who’s the Dupe? and it was very dull.

22. Attended Court the whole day— It pass’d in various arguments rather preparatory than upon the merits of any of the Causes. The ladies spent the Evening at Mrs: Dexter’s, where I went to them, towards its close— I read part of the first Volume of Boswell’s life of Johnson.

23. We dined at Dr: Welsh’s, and pass’d the Evening, with his family, at Mr: S. A. Otis’s.— Judge Cushing, and his Lady were also there— I spent the day in Court; but there was yet no Cause to the Jury— The Counsel who transact principally the business of this Court are Messrs: Parsons, Sullivan, Dexter, Otis, R. Amory, G. Blake, (the District Attorney) and Charles Jackson, a young Gentleman of promising talents, patronized by Mr: Parsons.— I have paid particular attention to their manner of speaking; and made several observations, which will escape me, for want of an opportunity to record them from day to day.

24. When we came from Quincy, we intended to have returned this day; but were prevented by the badness of the weather— The first Cause of much interest at this Term was opened this day to the Jury; but not finished— A question upon the violation of a patent right— On a machine for making twill’d cotton Cards— I spent part of the Evening with Mr: Dexter.

25. The cause of Earle vs Earle, on the question of a patent right was this day closed— Mr: Parsons in finishing for the plaintiff discovered considerable knowledge on the principles of mechanics. No other man at the bar, has such various and extensive knowledge; and no man has such a faculty of making his knowledge on all subjects, useful in his profession— We spent the Evening at Mr: H. Otis’s; where we met a Mr: and Miss Clifton of Philadelphia, two Miss Cary’s, and Mr: Charles Bradbury.

26.— The weather was again so bad that we were prevented from returning home this day.— My Sister however returned from Cambridge— I pass’d the Evening principally with Mr: Shaw at his Office— Finished this morning, the Racines Grecques, the second time. This exercise is the only one which I have continued without interruption; but my application even to this, for the last fortnight, has been so unavoidably affected, that I have very imperfectly performed my daily tasks— So I shall have to go over them again— Eveg: Dr: Welsh’s.

27. Began upon the Racines Grecques the third time; and I now charge myself with ten Stanza’s at a time.— Went with Mr: Gardner to the Brattle-Square Church, and heard Mr: Buckminster, with whom I was very well pleased. Dined with Mr: Gardner, and in the afternoon went with him to the West-Boston Church (Dr: Howard’s) where I heard Mr: Charles Lowell, the late Judge Lowell’s youngest Son— He has very lately returned from Edinburgh where he went to finish his professional Education, and is not settled— He has talents and is a good Speaker. I spent the Evening, partly at Judge Davis’s, and partly with Mrs: Adams, at Mr: Smith’s— At the Judge’s I met a Mr: M’Clure, a Clergyman residing at Windsor in Connecticut; and Coll: May.— At Mr: Smith’s, a Mr: Cruft.

28. I dined with Mr: Jackson, the Treasurer of the State; in Company with his Son Charles, Messrs: F. & C. Lowell, Gardner, Dutton, and Strong, the Governor’s eldest Son; a Miss Searle of Newbury-Port was also there— Evening at home— Mr: Osgood call’d on me, and I agreed to look over his house with him, to-morrow morning.

29. I went this morning, and looked over Mr: Osgood’s house with him; which would suit me very well— But the price he asks for it, is higher than I can give— Captain Beale and Mr: T. Greenleaf called upon me, and invited me to dine with a company of Gentlemen at Quincy to-morrow— I intended to have gone out in the Stage this afternoon; but went with Mr: Davenport to look at his houses in Cambridge-port; which detained me untill it was too late— The juries at the Circuit Court were this day dismiss’d— The Causes of Church against the underwriters were all discontinued; the papers duly authenticated having arrived from Lisbon; and his Counsel did not choose to venture another trial— They threaten however to renew the suit in the State Courts. Evening at home— We have had as fellow-boarders Mr: Morris an Officer in the Navy, and Mr: Hort an Englishman; lately arrived in this Country.

30. At length the boy, came in with a Chaise for us and we returned to Quincy. Mrs: Adams went immediately home— I dined with the Company at Newcomb’s— It was much less numerous than when I last dined with them on the same anniversary; which was in 1802.— I left them soon after dinner, and came home— Walk’d with Mrs: Adams down to my fathers, where we spent the Evening, with much company. Captn: R. C. Beale last Evening being on his return from Boston, overset his Chaise, and broke his thigh.
31. Mr: Apthorp called on me this morning, respecting a Will to be made by his wife.— I went to my father’s this afternoon; but returned home very early in the Evening; Mrs: Adams being quite unwell.

Day. Untill the last ten days, my occupations and their order have been exactly the same as the last month. But while in Boston my course of life was different— I rose at about 7.— Studied the Racines Grecques untill 9. Breakfasted— Attended the Circuit Court untill 1 or 2.— Went into State-Street for a few minutes— Then home to dinner at Whitcomb’s—Concert Hall; where we lodged— In the afternoon attended the Court again untill its adjournment, usually between 5 and 6. And spent the Evening, either in Company abroad, or at our lodgings reading Boswell’s life of Johnson— Of which I went through only the first Volume.— The only part of my studies which during my visit to Boston was not entirely suspended, was the Racines Grecques; and even to them my application was much more interrupted than at Quincy— I have learnt them through by heart the second time and have begun upon them the third— It now takes me about the same time to learn ten Stanza’s, as at the first impression I was employed by three.— I hope not to leave them, untill they shall be perfectly mastered.— My visit to Boston has been a relaxation, and had I taken care to write from day to day my observations would have been itself a useful Study— But I suffered them to escape me, and shall therefore derive no benefit from it.
